W. W. Smith. University of Massachusetts. Amherst: "I am really here in four
capacities: as an interested member, as a member of the arrangements committee, as
a representative of the U. of M., and as a member of the WMETV Inc. The TV Council
includes the University, and all the colleges in the valley plus some other groups
in the area. We have expanded this Council to include other phases than just
educators. There was no channel for this area, but we have been assigned Channels
BO and 82 for the Amherst area and Mt. Greylock. The University hopes to go into
TV in the not too far distant future and we are making our plans through this TV
Council. This is one place in the U.S. where UHF is really doing well, and for this
our location is very important. Being halfway between New York and Boston, we pick
up what the other stations do not."
Rav Wyman. Director. Audio Visual Instruction, University of Massachusetts;
"I am director of AVA at the University of Massachusetts and one of the three
advisors to our campus station WMUA, whose call letters appear on this microphone,
and which is our honest 10 watt station.”
Ralnh RourkeT WFUV. Fordham University: nI represent WFUV, Fordham!s FM
Station. We are on the air 365 days a year, with no time out for an annual picnic,
and run from 9s00 A.M. to 11:00 P.M. We do no in-school broadcasting, make no
effort to appeal to anyone not of university level and direct everything to this
level, for, you understand, we have some considerable competition in New York City.
Our three main purposes are to increase adult education, to provide a training for
males and females in industry and to use our facilities as a laboratory for the
development of new programs and new ideas. TV is just a word at the moment with us.
